title: 114_s278
content: The "Citizen Empowerment Act" is a new amendment to Part III of title 5, United States Code, adding a new chapter 79A for services to members of the public. The "Citizen Empowerment Act" adds procedures for in-person and telephonic interactions conducted by executive branch employees, defining terms like 'covered interaction' and 'telephonic'. The "Citizen Empowerment Act" allows individuals to record interactions with executive branch employees at their own expense. Employees can also record interactions but must inform the individual and provide a transcript upon request with reimbursement. Employees must also explain rights before or at an initial interaction. Before or at an initial covered interaction, individuals must be provided with a verbal or written notice of their rights. Separate notifications are required for separate violations. Official representatives or those holding power of attorney can make audio recordings and receive transcripts as if they were the individual. The individual making an audio recording shall receive the same notice as the individual, have rights to the recording and transcript, and the recording is the individual's property. There is no private right of action, and exceptions apply for classified information, public safety, and criminal investigations. The text discusses exceptions to the right to make an audio recording of interactions, including situations where it may endanger public safety or an ongoing criminal investigation. Employees must notify individuals if an exception applies, and this section supersedes certain laws regarding recording interactions. Employees of Executive agencies must adhere to the rules regarding recording covered interactions, with disciplinary action for violations.
